By burning all agricultural waste such as corn and rice stalks, branch and leaf litter( as well as animal dung) in a ''low-oxygen'' environment to create charcoal, we could halt the increase and actually decrease the level of atmospheric carbon by 0.7 gigatonnes a year, according to Johannes Lehmann , a soil science expert at Cornell University. The bonus is that charcoal in the soil tends to increase crop yields, too. 3 comments from readers Simon Cowell Divine 16 January 2011
